The author of the Eructavit draws from many sources, some of which I cannot identify. Probably much of his material is the commonplace of medieval clerioal thought. Some of it is osten found in several writers, who may have been accessible. We may safely assume that there was some growth in the library of st. Pierre·le-Vif in the fifty years that followed 1123. We may assume also that occasionally in the scriptorium or cloister, the memory of a follow-monh furnished a quotation or a thought which the poet was able to use without consulting any boolr.

His manner 01 handlingmaterials borrowed from others is by no means servile. Whether he deals with generally current thought or something that clerks only know, the poet puts into it something of his own. He at least chooses, arranges or expands in his own way.
